Name: fairfax_county_2007_pol
Originator: Fairfax County GIS Branch Department of Information Technology
OriginatorSort: Fairfax County GIS Branch Department of Information Technology
Abstract: Geographic boundary, portraying extent and limits of land recognized as Fairfax County, Commonwealth of Virginia.  Defined in part by both physical features (Potomac and Occoquan Rivers), and monumented legal boundaries for surrounding jurisdictions (State of Maryland, Arlington, Loudoun, and Prince William Counties, cities of Alexandria and Falls Church).
FgdcText:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="no"?>
<metadata>
  <idinfo>

</citeinfo>
    </citation>
    <descript>
      <abstract>Geographic boundary, portraying extent and limits of land recognized as Fairfax County, Commonwealth of Virginia.  Defined in part by both physical features (Potomac and Occoquan Rivers), and monumented legal boundaries for surrounding jurisdictions (State of Maryland, Arlington, Loudoun, and Prince William Counties, cities of Alexandria and Falls Church).</abstract>
      <purpose>To cartographically depict the jurisdictional limits within Fairfax County. </purpose>
      <supplinf>
Boundary is relatively static, with only minor annexation adjustments over the last 40 years.

There is not one number for the size of the county that should be used in all cases.  Which number should be used depends on the purpose.  Water is not included in  density calculations (not by Census and not by us).  Thus when reporting population density or other density figures, the associated land area should be used (i.e. 395 square miles).  When the total land and water area is desired, I would suggest using the 406.8 square miles calculated by GIS.  GIS uses a more precise geographical system than the Census Bureau and GIS has the ability to update this figure as intercensal changes occur.  In most public documents land area is the figure most quoted because it is tied to population density but that does not mean that it should be the only one used.  When numbers are quoted for square miles they should be properly annotated:

395 square miles (land area)
406.8 square miles (land and water area)

In addition, you will find other figures appearing in Demographic Reports documents.  These figures are based on real estate parcel information and include only zoned and developable land (water, roads and other nondevelopable land are not included).

This information comes from the U.S. Census.   In determining these "official" numbers, the following sources have been contacted:

- State's Commission on Local Government
- Weldon Cooper's Center
- Northern Virginia Regional Commission
- Virginia Geographic Information Network
- Virginia Department of Transportation
</supplinf>
    </descript>

  <dataqual>
    <attracc>
      <attraccr>Boundaries are derived from a combination of ground monumentation and legal documents (Charters, grants, etc.).  Their positional portrayal is considered accurate in relation to known features.</attraccr>
    </attracc>
    <logic>Polygon topology exists.</logic>
    <complete>Data is 100% complete.  Accuracy confidence level for this layer is in excess of 98%.</complete>
    <posacc>
      <horizpa>
        <horizpar>Horizontal positional accuracy for the digital data is tested by visual comparison of the source with hard copy plots.</horizpar>
      </horizpa>
      <vertacc>
        <vertaccr>A formal accuracy assessment of the vertical positional information in the data set has either not been conducted, or is not applicable.</vertaccr>
      </vertacc>
    </posacc>

      <procstep>
        <procdesc>Data copied from the CD obtained from Fairfax County, VA 2007.
Selected lines from property mylars that make up the political jurisdictions within Fairfax County. Put these lines into the political jurisdiction coverage. Built coverage for polygon topology.  Loaded data into SDE.</procdesc>

      <fees>Wall Map Data. This data set includes over 30 layers of attributed vector map data that were derived primarily from the Fairfax County 1"= 2000' and 1"= 4000' Wall Map Series. The GIS Wall Map CD in Coverage format sells for $25. The GIS Wall Map CD in Shapefile format sells for $25. A hard copy of our *wall maps are available at the Fairfax County Government Publications Center located at the Fairfax County Government Center Building - 12000 Government Center Pw.- Fairfax - VA. - Suite 156 - Phone # 703-324-2974 or 703-324-2975. Prices range from $1.50 to $15.00.* Some of our hard copy maps are not for sale to the public or may be out of stock. Contact the Fairfax County Publication Center on the availabilty of which maps can be purchased.</fees>
    </stdorder>
